resources.string: File is not the correct format.
Not enough space to import entire folder.
Deleted file exceeds recycle bin size. Delete permanently? (Note: Size can be edited in settings)
Recycle bin does not exist. Files will be deleted directly.
Generic images (ex: jpg) have been disabled in settings.
is an invalid label. Labels can be customized in settings.
You tried to apply an empty watermark. Please add text.

Unfortunately your device is running Android 4.4+. Google disabled writing to sdcards in this version. There are two options to continue using sdcards:
1:Use an external card reader.
2:Root your device to fix it.

Without a fix you CANNOT edit, save or create metadata on sdcards.
You have selected a folder that has write access disabled.
You have selected a folder that has write access disabled. Google disabled sdcard write access in Android 4.4.
Space allocated to recycle bin (Default: 50MB, Min: 30MB, Max: 500MB)\nBe careful with size, 500MB is over 6% of an 8GB device!
If disabled deletes will not require confirmation even if they exceed recycle bin size.
When disabled images will be directly deleted.
This will show xmp sidecar files in the gallery.
This will show jpg, gif, bmp, and png.
This will show files that RawDroid does not process.
Click to import a tab-delimited keyword file, such as that exported from Lightroom.
Check only if you experience issues with the default viewer.\nPlease email me if this is necessary.
There was an error communicating with Google servers. Make sure you are connected and try again later.
Application was modified! Uninstall apps designed to crack licensing. There are also reports of some ad blocking software making modifications. You may need to reinstall afterwards.
All features are available. Thank you for your support!
Click to manually check the license. Requires an internet connection.
Enable to place watermark on exported photos.
This is the pixel size of the text as opposed to a font size.\nFor large images this should be > 100.
Click to send me an email.
Distance from left edge of image to left edge of watermark.
Distance from right edge of image to right edge of watermark.
Distance from top edge of image to top edge of watermark.
Distance from bottom edge of image to bottom edge of watermark.
(Android 4.4+) Hide nav and status bars until swiped in.
Click here to upgrade to Rawdroid Pro to unlock features and improve speed!

If you enjoy using RawDroid please take a moment to rate it.

If you've rated based on a bug that is now fixed please update your rating.

Thanks for your support!

RawDroid will operate as a fully functional demo with watermarking until RawDroid Pro is purchased. You are free to test all features on your device until you choose to upgrade.

If you have any issues you can submit a bug report or email me via the help menu.

Would you like to run the tutorial now (You can run it later at Help:Tutorial)?
Would you like to run the tutorial now (You can run it later at Help:Tutorial)?

Google disabled write access. You may grant Rawdroid write access in the following window. If you decline Rawdroid will be view images but will be unable to write metadata, delete, save thumbnails, etc. Rawdroid will ONLY be able to access the folder you select, so the safest bet is to choose the whole sd card restoring previous access permissions to Rawdroid. Write access is used ONLY for actions related to image workflow.

Google disabled write access in Android 4.4. Without write access you cannot edit metadata, write xmp, delete, etc. You have three options:
 1) Use an external reader connected via OTG USB.
 2) Upgrade to 5.0. There is a fix in 5.0.
 3) Root your device and apply a fix.
No images were found. If you know there are images on the device, please contact me to investigate why search failed. Thank you for testing the beta!
Empty database detected. Would you like to search the device for images? You may manually search by pressing the following menu item.
Thank you for joining the beta!

Welcome to the Rawdroid 4.0 beta. The beta is built upon a completely redesigned framework. At the expense of initially processing images you now have the benefit of instantaneous filter and search (coming soon), as well as an even faster browsing and viewing experience.

 This is still a very early beta, so please do not use this to process your precious images on your next trip.

 With a change this massive and the multitude of devices this app services, your assistance in this beta is invaluable.
 Do not hesitate to post a bug/enhancement on the issue-tracker (there is a link where you signed up for the beta).

 Thank You!
The tutorial is interactive and can be advanced by clicking the next button.
There are three main ways to access your images in Rawdroid.
Insert an SD card directly into your device. Not all devices have an sd slot, and obviously not all cameras store on SD.

Alternatively you can connect the camera directly. Just like on your PC this method is slow. Due to limitations in Android we cannot write to cameras, so this will import images to your device.\nYour device must have enough storage. More details on the website.

Finally you can connect your media card with a card reader and OTG cable. This is the best way to use Rawdroid. It is far faster than importing. A single format card reader is best.\n\ta. Some devices will require root. Unfortunately my nexus did. There are more details on this case on the website.
(Future addition) Eventually I will be adding network support.
How Do I Find My Images
You can connect an external reader via a USB OTG cable. \'Find USB\' will attempt to find the mounted media.
If you import from the camera it should take you to the destination when complete.

Finally if needed you can also navigate manually much like a file explorer. Try clicking \'tutorial\'. That messy path is where the tutorial is temporarily stored. You can use this to help navigate to your images. When in doubt start at \'\\mnt\'
If you always use the same location Rawdroid should attempt to automatically open it on startup.
You can quickly use \'Search\' to find any folders with images on your device.
You can begin selecting images at any time by LONG pressing on an image for two seconds. Try it on image 1.
You can add images to the selection by QUICKLY pressing on them. Try that on image 3.
You have now selected just images 1 and 3.
You can quickly select all with this button. Try that now.
You can exit the selection mode by clicking the back button. Try that now.
You can also select a range of images by long pressing on the beginning and end image. Enter selection mode by LONG pressing on image 2.
Now LONG press again on image 4.
You have selected images 2 and 3 and 4.
Press this button to rename selected images within a few templates (more coming soon).
This will move selected images to a new location. This can be used to import, export, or simply organize images.
This will export a compressed jpeg thumbnail of the selected images to a desired location.
This will convert the selected images to jpeg and share with another app.

If enabled in settings deleted images will be kept in a recycling bin. The bin has a limited size and will permanently delete the oldest images when it is full. You can recover images with this button.
If you forget what an icon does you can always long-press it for the title. Press this icon for two seconds now.
Long press any image to enter selection mode.
You can also select all images with this button. Try that now.
This will open the recycling bin allowing you to restore deleted items.
This will go to the most recently decoded folder.
This will share the selected files with the given application.
This will delete all selected images.
While in selection mode another long press on an image will select between the last selection.
This will rename all selected files with a selected template.
This will import selected images to a new destination.
This will export selected images as a compressed jpeg thumbnail.
There are three ways to access data:
1. Fastest: Transfer images to your device via PC connection. Obviously not an ideal use.

2. Fast: Connect your media card with a card reader and OTG cable. A single format card reader is best.\n\ta. Some devices will require root. My nexus did. I use "StickMount" to connect. More details on the website.
\ta. Some devices will require root. My nexus did. I use "StickMount" to connect. More details on the website.

3. Slow: Connect your camera with an OTG cable. Due to limitations in Android we cannot write to cameras, this will import images to your device.\nYour device must have enough storage. More details on the website.
4. Eventually I will be adding network support.
If you have an older device that crashes, this is likely due to memory limitations.\nI recommend rooting and using "VM Heap Tool" to allow more memory.
This is the current path. You can quickly navigate the drop-down.
Long press action items to see a short description.
This will search known mount points for any USB devices. If your device is not found please email the mount point ex:"/mnt/weird/device/usb"
